column1: Don Quixote persuaded a certain labourer
column4: but one of very shallow wit
column5: to go away with him and serve him as squire. In the end he gave him so many fair words and promises that the poor fellow determined to go with him. Don Quixote
column7: told him that he ought to be very pleased to depart with him
column8: for at some time or other an adventure might befall which should in the twinkling of an eye win him an island and leave him governor thereof. On the faith of these and other like promises
column9: Sancho Panza (for so he was called) forsook his wife and children and took service as squire to his neighbour.Whilst they were journeying along
column10: Sancho Panza said to his master: "I pray you have good care
column12: that you forget not that government of the island which you have promised me
column13: for I shall be able to govern it be it never so great."
